channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Battered Ukrainian City, the Latest Battle is Against Winter
item.description: Firefighters in Lyman, in Ukraine’s east, contend with land mines, freezing temperatures, damaged buildings, awful cell service and a lack of water.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Yermak and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: A firefighter from Emergency Service Department Number 21, the single working fire station in Lyman, Ukraine, extinguishing a fire in an abandoned home this month.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Thwarted Another Drone Strike on Kyiv
item.description: The authorities in Kyiv said that Russia had followed the previous day’s missile strikes with seven more drones, but that Ukrainian air defenses had shot them down.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

item.title: Xi and Putin Meet Again, Two Strongmen in a Weak Moment
item.description: Russia is isolated by its invasion of Ukraine and needs China more than ever. But China, facing a Covid crisis, is in no position to risk sanctions.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia speaking on Friday from Moscow via video with China’s leader, Xi Jinping.

item.title: 100 Years Since the Birth of the Soviet Union, in Pictures
item.description: It is the disintegration of the U.S.S.R. that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia says he wants to remedy by waging war against Ukraine; it is the legacy of Moscow’s dominance that Ukrainians hope to free themselves of by defeating Moscow.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Communist Party supporters laid flowers at Stalin’s grave in Moscow this month, marking the anniversary of his birth.

item.title: They Said They Went to Mali to Keep the Peace. Now They’re Jailed as Mercenaries.
item.description: Ivory Coast said its soldiers were in Mali to provide security for the United Nations peacekeeping mission. But Mali accused them of seeking to undermine its own security.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Mamadou Tapily and Loucoumane Coulibaly
item.category: Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: Ivorian soldiers supporting the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Mali on parade in Abidjan during the 59th anniversary of Ivory Coast’s independence in 2019.

item.title: A Cop Called Coco, an Actor Named Mani, a Quebecer Exploring Quebec
item.description: When Mani Soleymanlou began acting, he was offered roles as stereotypical outsiders. That he now stars as a cop named Coco is indicative of broader shifts in a changing Quebec.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Renaud Philippe
item.media:description: Mani Soleymanlou at his home in Montreal in November.

item.title: In the Pacific, Outcry Over Japan’s Plan to Release Fukushima Wastewater
item.description: The proposal has angered many of Japan’s neighbors, particularly those with the most direct experience of unexpected exposure to dangerous levels of radiation.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tanks storing radioactive water at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in Japan. The government plans to release the water, treated, but still slightly radioactive, into the Pacific starting in spring 2023.

item.title: Attack on Oil Workers in Eastern Syria Kills at Least 10
item.description: No group claimed responsibility for the assault on a bus convoy. But Islamic State militants remain active in parts of Syria and have increased attacks in the area, which is government-controlled.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Hwaida Saad
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Aung San Suu Kyi Gets 33 Years in Prison in Myanmar
item.description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi has faced a series of charges since being detained in a coup in early 2021. Her trials came to an end on Friday, capping months of legal proceedings.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Matt Stevens
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Koen Van Weel/Anp, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi before the United Nations’ International Court of Justice in the Peace Palace of The Hague, in 2019.

item.title: Pelé, the Global Face of Soccer, Dies at 82
item.description: Pelé, who was declared a national treasure in his native Brazil, achieved worldwide celebrity and helped popularize the sport in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Lawrie Mifflin
item.media:description: Pelé during a game at Giants Stadium in New Jersey in 1977, when he played for the New York Cosmos of the North American Soccer League.

item.title: Moscow on the Med: A Faraway War Transforms a Turkish Resort Town
item.description: Tens of thousands of Russians and Ukrainians have settled in Antalya, on Turkey’s southern coast, hoping to avoid the fallout of Russia’s war in Ukraine and start new lives.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The waterfront in the Turkish resort town of Antalya in December.

item.title: Israel’s Hard-Line Government Takes Office, Testing Bonds With Allies
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing coalition will likely test ties with the United States and Europe, amid fears that it will undermine the country’s democracy and stability.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu with Itamar Ben-Gvir, the minister of national security, after being sworn in at the Knesset, Israel’s Parliament, in Jerusalem on Thursday.

item.title: White Men Charged in Attack on Black Teenagers at Pool in South Africa
item.description: Two youths who tried to use a pool at a resort on Christmas Day said they were told it was for “white people only.” The violent encounter led to a charge of attempted murder and a call by the president to battle racism.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon

item.title: Japan’s Ski Mecca, Niseko, Is Desperate for Workers
item.description: Japan reopened its borders just in time for the winter season. The Niseko area is straining to meet the pent-up demand.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists in Kutchan, Japan, earlier this month. The ski resort area of Niseko has been struggling with a lack of workers this winter season.

item.title: Juan Guaidó Is Voted Out as Leader of Venezuela’s Opposition
item.description: The vote to terminate the interim government signaled that members of the opposition had lost faith in Mr. Guaidó’s ability to oust President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Isayen Herrera and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Juan Guaidó took the leadership of Venezuela’s opposition in 2019.

item.title: Ukraine Defeats Russian Drone Swarm, as NATO Head Says Kyiv Needs More Arms
item.description: In a war where the vital weapons and tactics have changed repeatedly, Ukraine relies more than ever on air defenses to fend off barrages aimed at its energy systems and cities.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cleaning up debris from Russian strikes near Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: Andrew Tate Is Charged With Human Trafficking and Rape in Romania
item.description: Mr. Tate, an online personality known for making misogynistic comments, and three others will be held in custody for 30 days, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: McKenna Oxenden and Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Andrew Tate was escorted outside the headquarters of the Directorate for the Investigation of Organized Crime and Terrorism in Bucharest, Romania, on Thursday.

item.title: Ahead of Major Court Case, E.P.A. Revises Clean-Water Protections
item.description: A new rule revives an older set of protections for rivers, marshes and waterways, setting aside changes in the Obama and Trump administrations that led to years of legal wrangling.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: The E.P.A. is taking the action before a Supreme Court decision that could limit the agency’s authority to act in the future.

item.title: ‘The Daily’ checks in with a Russian man who fled the draft.
U.S. Saw Continuing Drop in Murders in 2022
item.description: The situation changed for the better in 2022.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Grand Central Station this year. Murders in large U.S. cities are down more than 5 percent so far this year compared to the same time last year.

item.title: Zelensky Signs Controversial News Media Regulation
item.description: Lawmakers who passed the bill said it would help meet European Union conditions for membership, but journalists have decried it as a move toward censorship.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: The U.S. Will Need Thousands of Wind Farms. Will Small Towns Go Along?
item.description: In the fight against climate change, national goals are facing local resistance. One county scheduled 19 nights of meetings to debate one wind farm.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times

item.title: Welcome to Little Kiwi, N.Y.C.
item.description: Young New Zealanders are once again venturing back out into the world.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Manhattan skyline viewed from Brooklyn.

item.title: Russian Missile Attack Overwhelms Ukraine’s Air Defenses
item.description: Cruise missiles and exploding drones from Iran swept across the skies of Ukraine, wreaking havoc and once again knocking out power.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s not a war,” one resident of Kyiv said. “It’s a crime against humanity.”

item.title: How Bad Is China’s Covid Outbreak? It’s a Scientific Guessing Game.
item.description: In the absence of credible information from the Chinese government, researchers around the world are looking for any clues to determine the size and severity of the surge.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passengers, including one wearing full-body protective gear, at the Shanghai Railway Station this month.

item.title: U.S. Says Chinese Fighter Jet Flew Dangerously Close to American Plane
item.description: The Chinese jet flew within 20 feet of the nose of an American military aircraft over the South China Sea this month, nearly causing a collision, the U.S. military said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A Chinese military plane came within 20 feet of a U.S. Air Force jet, in this still image taken from a video provided by the Defense Department.

item.title: Unlikely Parallels in a Year of Momentous Deaths
item.description: The deaths of luminaries like Queen Elizabeth II and Bill Russell did not necessarily surprise. Others, though, inscrutably departed seemingly in tandem.
item.dc:creator: William McDonald
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Barton Silverman/The New York Times; Ike Edeani for The New York Times; Chris Jackson/Getty Images; Sam Falk/The New York Times; Evening Standard/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images; Erin Schaff/The New York Times; Mario Tama/Getty Images; Associated Press; Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times; Mario Ruiz/EPA, via Shutterstock; Jurek Wajdowicz
item.media:description: Top row, from left: Pelé, André Leon Talley, Queen Elizabeth II and Sidney Poitier. Middle row: Christine McVie and Shinzo Abe. Bottom row, from left: Madeleine Albright, Bill Russell, Ivana Trump, Olivia Newton-John and Urvashi Vaid.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Israel’s New Government
item.description: Also, Russia strikes Ukraine, Pelé dies and the week in culture.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Newly sworn in Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu attends a cabinet meeting in Jerusalem on Thursday.

item.title: Algeria Cracks Down on Last Remaining Independent Media Outlet
item.description: The country has effectively closed down one of the last places in Algeria for freewheeling political debate, which carried on even as the military-backed regime that leads the country grew increasingly authoritarian.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A protest by state television employees against censorship in Algiers in 2019.

item.title: Pictures of the Year
item.description: Some of the most memorable photos published in The Times in 2022.
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: China Covid: U.S. Testing Rule Meets a Collective Shrug
item.description: The U.S. travel rule drew a muted response in a country grappling with outbreaks and where mass, regular Covid testing was up until recently a daily reality for many millions of people.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Amy Chang Chien, Claire Fu and Tiffany May
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: An Air China passenger jet at the Beijing Capital International Airport in October.

item.title: The Biden administration tries to stop Iran from supplying Russia with drones.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers combing through the rubble of a residential building in Kyiv that a Russian drone hit in October.

item.title: Fire at Cambodian Casino Near Thai Border Kills at Least 19
item.description: The blaze at Grand Diamond City also injured at least 60 people, officials said. Guests at the 17-story complex jumped from windows to escape the flames.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Sun Narin
item.media:description: Firefighters battling the fire at the Grand Diamond City casino in Poipet, Cambodia, on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine gives an optimistic update on its power grid, but concern grows about coming holidays.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A power generator in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, in December. Many areas of the country are experiencing power outages from Russia strikes on energy infrastructure.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: New requirements for passengers coming from China.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A medical worker performing a Covid test in Danzhai, China.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: The U.S. Requires Covid Tests for Travelers From China
item.description: Also, Ukraine peace talks seem far-off.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Tourists could help China rescue its faltering economy.

item.title: Hard-Line Positions by Russia and Ukraine Dim Hope for Peace Talks
item.description: Both Moscow and Kyiv say they are ready to talk, but their terms for sitting down at a negotiating table suggest otherwise.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in the capital, Kyiv, attending the funeral of a director, Oleh Bobalo, killed in fighting against Russian forces near Bakhmut in the Donetsk region.

item.title: US to Require Negative Covid Tests for Travelers From China
item.description: Amid concerns about a coronavirus surge in Beijing, the Biden administration announced the change in policy for those entering the United States from China, including Hong Kong and Macau.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Benjamin Mueller
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A medical worker performing a Covid test in Danzhai, China.

item.title: Exxon Mobil Sues to Try to Block EU Windfall Tax
item.description: European subsidiaries of the American oil giant filed a lawsuit with a European Union court seeking to stop the tax, which Exxon Mobil said could cost it billions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Exxon Mobil storage tanks in the Netherlands in 2021.

item.title: Lawmakers Signal Inquiries Into US Government’s Use of Foreign Spyware
item.description: The moves come as Congress passed a measure last week to try to rein in the proliferation of the hacking tools.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Representative Adam Schiff, the chairman of the Intelligence Committee, asked the Drug Enforcement Administration for detailed information on its use of an Israeli spyware tool.

item.title: Ali Daei’s Family Is Targeted After He Supports Iran Protests
item.description: The wife and daughter of the soccer star Ali Daei, one of the most prominent critics of Iran’s crackdown on protesters, were stopped from leaving Iran.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Mohammad Karamali/DeFodi Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ali Daei at the draw for the 2022 World Cup, in Doha, Qatar, in April.

item.title: Israel’s New Hard-Line Government Raises Hackles Ahead of Inauguration
item.description: The country’s president warned the far-right incoming minister of national security that he was raising alarms at home and abroad over racism, discrimination and undermining democracy.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Itamar Ben-Gvir, the leader of the ultra-nationalist party Jewish Power, campaigning in Jerusalem in October ahead of the elections. Mr. Ben-Gvir will lead national security efforts for the new government.

item.title: The Hardy Tree, a Beloved Fixture of a London Cemetery, Topples Over
item.description: The tree, named after the author Thomas Hardy, was surrounded by 18th- and 19th-century gravestones. It was a popular site for locals and tourists.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. James Elston, right, of the St. Pancras Old Church in London, pointing out damage on Tuesday after a famous tree associated with the novelist Thomas Hardy fell over.

item.title: Denmark May End Great Prayer Day Holiday as It Seeks to Bolster Military
item.description: A proposal by Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen would eliminate one public day off from work in an effort to increase spending on defense.
item.dc:creator: Jasmina Nielsen
item.media:credit: Liselotte Sabroe/Ritzau Scanpix, via AFP — Getty Images
item.media:description: “I personally think that it is a relatively cheap price to pay as a country with war on its own continent,” Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark, center, said of the plan.

item.title: As China Drops Travel Rules, Wariness Rises Over its Covid Outbreak
item.description: Many welcomed Beijing’s plan to loosen quarantine rules for travelers, but concerns linger about the country’s Covid wave.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che, Claire Fu and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Travelers passing through Beijing Capital International Airport on Tuesday. On Jan. 8, entry rules for visitors to China will be eased.

item.title: Former Pope Benedict XVI Is ‘Very Ill,’ Francis Says
item.description: Francis called on the faithful to offer up support for his 95-year-old predecessor as the Vatican said that the retired pope’s health had deteriorated in recent hours.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Vatican Media, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The retired Pope Benedict XVI, left, with Pope Francis at the Vatican in 2020.

item.title: China’s New Covid Chapter
item.description: The end of the country’s restrictions has exposed two major vulnerabilities.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Covid patients in the lobby of a hospital in Chongqing, China, on Friday.

item.title: South Koreans’ Steely Nerves Are Shaken by North Korean Drones
item.description: With tensions on the Korean Peninsula on the rise, many in the South were rattled when five drones from the North successfully crossed the border without being shot down.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A news story on multiple North Korean drones flying into South Korean airspace was broadcast at a train station in Seoul on Monday.

item.title: As Remote Workers Flock to Mexico City, Airbnb and Housing Prices Soar
item.description: American and Europeans are using Airbnb to find long-term rentals in Mexico’s capital, pushing housing costs higher and, critics say, forcing out local residents.
item.dc:creator: David Shortell and Alejandro Cegarra
item.media:description: The Victoria building in Mexico City was sold to be converted into short-term rentals, displacing 25 Mexican families.

item.title: U.S. Scrambles to Stop Iran From Providing Drones for Russia
item.description: As the war in Ukraine grinds on, some officials have become convinced that Iran and Russia are building a new alliance of convenience.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers combing through the rubble of a residential building in Kyiv that a Russian drone hit in October.

item.title: Wild and Wilde: At Celebrity Cemetery, Nature Takes on Starring Role
item.description: Père-Lachaise in Paris, whose tombs of Oscar Wilde, Jim Morrison, Édith Piaf and many other artistic icons have made it a popular tourist draw, has become a haven for wildlife, too.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The grounds of Père-Lachaise cemetery, once a landscape with few signs of life, have been transformed into a lush garden since Paris banned pesticides there.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: China’s medical system is buckling under the strain of thousands of Covid infections.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Overwhelmed and understaffed, hospitals in China are struggling with a crush of Covid patients whose numbers are growing since Beijing dropped pandemic restrictions.

item.title: Pavel Antov, Founder of Russian Meat Company, Dies in India
item.description: The body of the millionaire Pavel Antov, who had reportedly criticized the Russian shelling of civilians in Kyiv, was found outside his hotel.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Suhasini Raj

item.title: Ukraine and Russia Battle for a Gateway City in the East
item.description: Recapturing Kreminna, in eastern Ukraine, would be a step further in Ukraine’s campaign to retake major cities that Russia seized after it invaded.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on their way to fight Russian forces in Kreminna, in eastern Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: China’s Overwhelmed Hospitals
item.description: Also, Ukraine is fighting to retake a city in the Donbas.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Southwest and Other Airline Meltdowns in Recent History
item.description: Flight delays and cancellations over the holiday weekend have left thousands of passengers stranded. Here’s a look at a few other notable episodes like it in recent memory.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delays and cancellations on Tuesday at Chicago Midway International Airport.

item.title: Ukraine’s Battered Economy Leaves It More Reliant on Foreign Aid.
item.description: Unable to roll over debt accumulated before the war, Ukraine has paid investors more than it has collected this year, the Central Bank says.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine’s economy was projected to shrink about 40 percent this year, with agriculture and other crucial sectors starkly affected by Russia’s invasion.

item.title: Lukashenko and Putin Affirm Their Close Ties Without Mention of Ukraine
item.description: Their meeting could add to fears that Moscow will try to draw Belarus, Ukraine’s northern neighbor, more directly into the war.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A photo distributed by the Russian state news media on Tuesday showing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, center, with Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, second from left, and other leaders at the Russian Museum in St. Petersburg.

item.title: Lee Myung-bak, South Korean Ex-President, Receives Pardon
item.description: The action by the current president, Yoon Suk Yeol, will release Mr. Lee from a 17-year sentence for bribery and embezzlement and nullify the enormous fines he owed.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon

item.title: Navalny Accuses Russian Prison Authorities of Using His Health as a Tool to Put Pressure on Him
item.description: The jailed Russian opposition leader said that he had been injected with unknown medication and accused the authorities of withholding his medical records.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny appeared via video link before a court hearing in Moscow in May.

item.title: Stories You Might Have Missed in 2022
item.description: Today we share stories that stood out to our editors but that you might have missed.
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning
item.media:description: A humpback whale breaching in waters off French Polynesia.
